displayed_text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, what, what other questions do you have? Patient: I read the, the, the information which you gave me. I - trepeditation about the, my actual response to all of this. And, I won’t know that until we start. So. I really don’t have anything other than - I wanna get it started. It’s my fourth visit, and you’re a great guy. But, next time, I want you to stick a needle in my arm or something. Doctor: Yeah. So, yeah we, you know, my problem with this stuff is, you know, the hormone therapy does good on it’s own. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we are adding more into it, so we can’t always tell you what the, um, adding in the chemo is gonna do. We can’t tell you what the surgery is gonna do. But, the outcome really is a number of men that don’t need therapy once we stop everything. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that would be great! If, you know, uh, we don’t see it - more, it is a zero. The testosterone has recovered. That would be ideal. Um. The next step is, you know, that we don’t get rid of your cancer with all of this and that your PSA goes up in the future. And, is that a longer time to get to that point or is it sort of like, even if we just did one thing, it’s all on-time? Patient: I do have one question. The, the rib. (pause) Doctor: Uh, because, we, we don’t normally cut out the ribs. I mean, that’s where we’re gonna offer radiation to that spot. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, that’s gonna treat that spot. Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be… Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can’t tell ya. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, unless we stick a needle into the bone and say, “Does cancer come out?” Patient: Right. Doctor: Or is this just a hole there? And, so, part of me has to figure out from what you are saying is - is it better or not better. You know, what’s different? You know, clearly under here, I feel like a quarter. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that is a specialized scan that is done either in Texas or in New York. Family Member: Yeah. We talked about that. Doctor: So you would have to go over there to get that scan before we can even decide if you should get the study or not. Family Member: So he’d have to have some blood work? Is it a blood draw? Is it, uh-? Doctor: For what? Family Member: To qualify for that. Patient: What do they do? Doctor: Oh, no. That’s a specialized scan. Yeah. I mean, he would definitely need a blood draw and all that. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All that screening would happen here. Family Member: Right.

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Before we started on the Xtandi and everything, you know the study. But since then we really barely even see those lymph nodes and even so they’ve been so small. Family Member: Great. Patient: So does that indicate that what your husband did worked? Family Member: Well no, that’s the bone scan. Doctor: No it doesn’t. Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And this what <___> I’m talking about so… Patient: Well I have an appointment with him next week. Doctor: The arms and hands are not something you can… Patient: No, no. Doctor: …get by easily without chuckles]]. Patient: So did you like Budapest? Doctor: Yes, it was interesting. I mean I had limited time, but it was… Patient: Yeah we did too. Doctor: I don’t think I would have ever thought of Budapest to visit if it weren’t for this meeting where I to be there. Patient: Yeah yeah right. Well we had been there. Doctor: It’s an incredible city. Oh my gosh! Like I never knew about, never thought about.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Which was like thirty. Patient: That there was no, there was no connection to prostate cancer in my genetic history? Doctor: Yeah. So these, these thirty genes or so that they test for, which are kind of very important cancer genes, you didn’t have any mutations of them. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: The uh, so the apricot seed. There was thing called, laetrile. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think it’s going to come pretty quickly. So the company that our group because our group invented it. It’s a company in France, that is a very experienced company developing new uh radioactive things. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That company just got bought by N___ Patient: Oh. Doctor: for five billion dollars. So there’s now a kind of uh a big shift. So I think it’s going to happen. Patient: So it’s going to be? Doctor: But up until now, it’s been this kind of almost called hit or miss, and just because of the way we did things in the U.S., it hasn’t. It’s been very frustrating. And I told you I went to Turkey to some little hospital taking care of this guy. We can give him We invented it. I can’t give it at my hospital. Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: So it’s been used in that way around the world but not, I’m not allowed to. Patient: That’s so tough. I see. Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany?

Patient: No. Doctor: Um hum. Have you been losing or gaining any weight? Patient: Uh, I guess I been Doctor: And do you think that’s because your appetite has dropped or you’re losing even if you’re eating the same amount. Patient: Somewhat the same amount. Doctor: Okay. And can you remind me who lives with you at home? Are you on your own or do you have other family members with you? Patient: Um my sister and my great-niece. Doctor: Sister and great-niece. A-and i-i-is your great-niece working or is she at home? Is she- Patient: She-she work. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhm. She probably gon’ be there Doctor: Okay. Well um, you might be right that the PSA level could be rising. We’ll find out by uh later this afternoon or tomorrow morning at the latest.

Patient: Yes, A1C and I could just give them to my doctor. Doctor: Okay, so a week before would be the week of January eighth. I’m just going to click on that day and I’ll click on the boxes approximate, so it will be any day of the week of January eighth – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - and then I’ll click on LabCorp. Patient: Uh hum, can you do multiple orders or do just have to be one order. Doctor: Each one is separate, so you can have three different pieces of paper printed out. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: One is going to be for the PSA, one is going to be for the testosterone and another is going to be for the A1C. Patient: Uh hum. I was wondering if we can make it a weekly, a monthly routine of bloodwork like . I’d rather not do that. Doctor: You won’t have monthly from that perspective he or she can Patient: Okay. Doctor: - at least for the short term. If something changes in the future, it might have to be more frequently. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, is it a mail-order thing? And if it’s crazy, is there a different thing we can do? Uh, the other thing to say about Zytiga, is it’s going to be generic soon, but I’m not sure it, if we’re quite there yet. I’m not sure. I can find that out. But, uh, so if you tell me, geez, I really don’t want to take prednisone, then I would do the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Otherwise, I would do the Zytiga. Patient: Yeah. I don’t really want to take prednisone. I saw how it affected her. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: But I was on a higher dose. You’re saying, uh, a lower dose. Doctor: Yeah. What dose were you on? Family Member: Uh, well, when I, I was diagnosed with Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: They had put me on like, it was like eighty milligrams, but then they brought me down because my face was all ballooned out. Doctor: And so this is five a day, five milligrams.

Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because we have the opportunity. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So here we are. (pause3sec) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Do you want the paperwork to read? Family Member: Yes, please. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh. When would be – when would we get started? Oh, you said you had to get approval through insurance? Doctor: Right. So we’re good. And K___ does the process. And then they almost map out all the days. Now, one thing that I like is you’re young, and your veins look pretty good. Instead of putting a catheter and all that in- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Which is a big to-do, I’m going to send you over there for an assessment. If they think they can just do it right off.

Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s one perspective, okay? Patient: Sure. Doctor: So the other thing, so we’ve got this fifty/fifty with the hormones and radiation. The question is what else can we do. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So what else we can do is we can hit what’s remaining as far as the cancer really hard right now and when I say really hard what we’re talking about is some chemotherapy, um which we give you through the vein every three weeks and we give you four doses of it. It’s a medicine called Taxotere. And we add in um uh, if we can get insurance to pay for it, but generally we can; we add in a super-hormone medicine called ah Zytiga or Addaram. It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day.

Family Member: No, I don’t make him work hard. It’s me. He’ll say oh you missed a spot and it’s like oh okay. Family Member: It’s okay. I get him to dust. He gets the easy stuff. Doctor: Alright. Family Member: I’ll do the rest. Doctor: Oh my gosh. You have a busy week. Okay so let me have S___ come in then. We’ll get that – all of those testing going. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay you’re not going over to the infusion today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh we’ll go from there. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Now prescription wise do you need anything? Patient: No.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah. That place is really nice. Doctor: Yeah. But I think the nice part with that is they you know people running out Patient: Yeah. Doctor: at Hopkins know Patient: Yeah. Doctor: this is a toll on people coming up every week. Patient: Yeah. Well, I, you know, I, I totally live, chemo would be logistically a problem. You know? I mean I’m, you know, I kind of dread it. I do. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I kind of knew it was coming but uh. What do you think the duration of that? Doctor: Of the treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So on a trial, it’s for eight treatments.
